sentences: Harold Campbell Adamson (December 10, 1906 – August 17, 1980) was an American lyricist during the 1930s and 1940s.
section: N/A
== Early life ==
== Early life ==

sentences: Adamson, the son of Harold Adamson and Marion "Minnie" Campbell Adamson, was born and raised in Greenville, New Jersey, United States.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Adamson suffered from polio as a child which limited the use of his right hand.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Initially, Adamson was interested in acting, but he began writing songs and poetry as a teenager.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: He went on to studying acting at the University of Kansas and Harvard.
section: == Early life ==
== Career ==
== Career ==

sentences: Ultimately he entered into a songwriting contract with MGM in 1933.
section: == Career ==

sentences: During his stint with MGM, he was nominated for five Academy Awards.
section: == Career ==

sentences: Among his best-known compositions was the theme for the hit sitcom, I Love Lucy.
section: == Career ==

sentences: He retired from songwriting in the early 1960s, and was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1972.
section: == Career ==

sentences: In 1941, he collaborated with Pierce Norman, and baseball's Joe DiMaggio to write "In the Beauty of Tahoe", published by Larry Spier, Inc..
section: == Career ==
